newsitem.title: USA: Analysts peg USDA cotton output at 17.96-18.8 mln bales.
newsitem.headline: Analysts peg USDA cotton output at 17.96-18.8 mln bales.

text.p: The U.S. Department of Agriculture is expected to peg the U.S. cotton crop at 17.96-18.8 million 480-lb bales, in its first supply and demand report for the new crop, analysts said.
The USDA put the current crop at 18.95 million bales, in its most recent estimate.
Exports in the 1997/98 season were pegged at 6.0-7.2 million bales, while domestic consumption was seen between 10.8-11.1 million bales.
Carryover could fall anywhere from 3.85-5.01 million bales, according to market analysts.
"Those numbers are very tentative," Carl Anderson, a cotton marketing specialist with Texas A&M University, said, pegging output at 18.8 million bales.
Anderson echoed the felling of each analyst surveyed, who stressed that the crop estimates are based on the USDA's prediction that planted area would reach 14.485 million acres.

Since March, when the USDA issued its planted area forecast, the market has seen weather-induced planting delays throughout the cotton belt, high soybean prices, and low prices for new-crop December futures.
As a result, the USDA is expected to trim its planted area estimate in July.
"If you put a gun to my head and forced me to use the perspective planting number," production would reach 18.05 million bales, Smith Barney analyst David Brandon, said.
He said growers are more likely to plant about 13.85 million acres of cotton by the end of the season.
Indeed, in its most recent progress report, the USDA said only 25 percent of the crop has been planted, compared with 31 percent a year ago and 37 percent in a five-year average.
"Planting delays should be watched closely from here on out, Rian Powell, an analyst with Allendale Inc, said.
Powell put output estimate at 17.96 million bales, the low end of the range, and said several more weeks of cool, wet weather in the Southeast chould damage yields considerably.

Analysts agreed that the USDA report is not likely to give the market a fundamental reason to rally from the contract lows hit earlier this week. In fact, prices are expected to weaken further by the fall, barring a severe weather or pest problem over the summer.
"Based on what we see now, we certainly should see lower prices this fall," Sharon Johnson, an analyst with Frank Schneider and Co Inc, said.
Her estimate for production came in at 18.0 million bales.
In the longer term, low prices may be just what the market needs to climb back to the 80.00 cent per lb range, analysts said.
"We'll sell more cotton overseas, increase demand, decrease ending stocks, and prices will rise," Johnson said.
